messageBody:
Ole,

I don't know that there any security risks to that approach.
Ultimately, security is more about who has access to your code rather
than anything that you do to protect it; any runtime can be fiddled with.

I would hesitate before using something like Class + ClassHelper as an
architectural style. It would be a shame to have to look at two things
whenever you used to have to look at one.

To me, the better thing is to notice when things are hard to test and
then decide whether to break your classes down into pieces where
operations can be public and whether, once public, they enable more in
your code. If you want to see an example of this, look at FIT
(fit.c2.com). I don't recall if it's that way now, but in the early
versions all methods were either public or package-scope. You have to
make some serious tradeoffs when you adopt that style for API code, but
in general it's a reasonable style for application (non-API) code.

Michael Feathers
www.objectmentor.com

Ole Ersoy wrote:

>Hi Guys,
>
>Would it be a good idea to always use all public
>methods...?
>
>In the context of a convention where there is a
>"MainClass" and a "MainClassHelper" that has public
>methods used to help the MainClass.
>
>Users of MainClassHelper (The collaborator should
>really be MainClass only) know that this class exists
>mainly for the purpose of helping MainClass, and all
>the methods are public, so that they can be easily
>unit tested.
>
>Otherwise they would be private or protected members
>of MainClass.
>
>So MainClassHelper can really be thought of as a
>utility library that is specific to MainClass...
>
>Anyone know if there are security risks to this,
>beside API risks?
>
>Thanks,
>- Ole
